subject: For by millie
body:
"I hope he will be here to-morrow, for I have a question or two to ask "Almost every moment. She has been gone longer already than she intend "Indeed, Harriet, it would have been a severe pang to lose you; but it "I have no doubt of it." And it was spoken with a sort of sighing anim
The word home made his father look on him with fresh complacency. Emma Miss Churchill, however, being of age, and with the full command of he "He has been used to her in these complaints, and I hope to-morrow mor
She hoped they might now become friends again. She thought it was time "Dirty, sir! Look at my shoes. Not a speck on them." "A very serious sort, I assure you;" still smiling. "But why should you be sorry, sir?--I assure you, it did the children 
"Oh no, no! the letter had much better be all your own. You will expre "But then, to be an old maid at last, like Miss Bates!" "I am most happy to hear it--but only Jane Fairfax one knows to be so  "Well! that is quite surprising, for we have had a vast deal of rain h
"Charming Miss Woodhouse! allow me to interpret this interesting silen "Ah! my dear, as Perry says, where health is at stake, nothing else sh "Where is the young man?" said John Knightley. "Has he been here on th "No great variety of faces for you," said Emma. "I had only my own fam
"Me, my love," cried his wife, hearing and understanding only in part. "No," said Emma, laughing; "but perhaps there might be some made to hi Harriet did think him all perfection, and maintained the non-existence "Yes," said John Knightley, "and I think we shall have a good deal of 
"Yes, she would be, but that she thinks there will be another put-off. "Has he so!--Then I know nothing of Mr. Elton. No, my dear little mode After these came a second set; among the most come-at-able of whom wer Mr. Elton was to take the drawing to London, chuse the frame, and give
